meta_data.title: Stephen Harkens Back to Nehemiah 9 in Acts 7, and Then Right After That He Gets Hit in the Head With Rocks Until He Dies
meta_data.subtitle: Nehemiah 9 & Acts 7 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. It's fast, fun, free, daily, deep-dye Bible, and right now we're working on the book of Nehemiah. If you're new, welcome. You can jump in right here, or you can always go back and start at the beginning of any season. The whole podcast is available in an easy-to-use format at thetmbh.com. We've had so much fun talking about Nehemiah chapter 9. I think I've used the term drink water in the desert in terms of reading through the Old Testament. It's great that it feels like the team you've been rooting for, the people you've been rooting for, have finally come around and all together collectively. In the fall of 444 BC, under the leadership of Ezra, they all get together here at the narrative part of the Old Testament, and they're like, God, you were right all along. And we were wrong all along. We were stiff-necked. We were stubborn. We refused to listen. Everything that is broken about the situation we now find ourselves in as subservient people in Persia. People are fault. And all we can do is throw ourselves at your mercy. All we can do is say that we get it, that we want your forgiveness, and that this is what we're going to do moving forward. We'll get into more of the specifics of what that this is, what we're going to do moving forward stuff looks like in Nehemiah chapter 10. It's just been beautiful. I love this part of the Bible. But you know how sometimes you watch a movie, you read a book, you watch a TV show, and it feels like it's kind of wrapping up. You're like, oh, everybody learned the lessons they needed to learn, the character arcs feel like they're about to resolve. But then you look at the runtime and you go, this isn't going to stick. There's a tension here that is yet unresolved. We have a long ways to go with this plot. Well, it's kind of the same thing with the Bible. You get to Nehemiah 9. Feels like maybe we've got it figured out, but then you have that many pages left. You figure out pretty quickly, okay, I got a whole testament to go here. This isn't going to totally work out. This is a nice step, but we're not done. And sure enough, even though great things happen in Nehemiah chapter 9, what we're going to discuss in the coming weeks as we land the plane on the book of Nehemiah is that some old problems that plagued the descendants of Abraham through the Old Testament get nipped in the bud right here. Want not really nipped in the bud. That means you cut it off before it took hold. They get addressed right here after centuries of struggling with those issues, things like intermarrying with their neighbors and then adopting their gods and their morality and rejecting God and worshiping idols. They move on from that. That's awesome. But also without the constant cycle of failure to keep them humble, a religious pride sets in and a certainty that their good behavior and that the system of rules and rules around rules and rules around rules to make sure no one misbehaves and sort of an integrated religious political state under the authority of Persia and then Alexander and his generals. And then later Rome, those things become a source of great confidence for these repentant people and their descendants after the events of Nehemiah chapter 9. Fast forward 450, 470 years after the events that we're reading here about Nehemiah. And Jesus has showed up the Messiah, the one who's going to be the cornerstone of God's whole redemptive plan, God in the flesh. This is what they were theoretically looking forward to all along. But a whole bunch of people, particularly the people who just happened to be in power and the religious leaders of the time of Jesus in the early first century, they were so spiritually damaged by their own pride and their own obsession with self over their newfound religious rigor that they don't recognize them. They don't know who Jesus is. And not only do they not sign up to follow Jesus or acknowledge him as Messiah, they actually have him killed kind of a big deal. That wasn't all the Jews who did this. Many followed the first followers or all Jewish people. Christianity catches on amongst the descendants of Abraham for sure. But the leaders, for the most part, they were unanimous in saying, not only do we not like Jesus, not only do we not recognize him as Messiah and the son of God, God in the flesh, but we're also going to work the system to make sure he gets dead as soon as possible. Well, jokes on them because as you read through the Bible, you figure out that God raises Jesus from the dead, just was predicted on the third day and Jesus sends to the right hand of the Father and is completely vindicated, legally, religiously, spiritually. Indeed, he is the king of the Jews. Indeed, he is the long-promised Messiah. Well, at the beginning of the book of Acts, Jesus ascends to the right hand of the Father and then the Holy Spirit shows up and starts guiding the followers of Jesus into the great unknown. They're going to go out and take the message of Christ, the Messiah, out into a world that some people are excited to hear it. Some people are really not excited to hear it. The first place they're commanded to go by Jesus is to Jerusalem. People in Jerusalem, remember, they just killed Jesus. They're not real high on this message. And in Acts, chapter seven, there's an early Christian leader, a young man named Stephen, who is steeped in the whole story, the whole narrative of the Old Testament, just like Nehemiah and Ezra are very knowledgeable about the whole story of the Old Testament and where they fit into it and where the people fit into it. Indeed, Ezra's prayer that he wrote in Nehemiah, chapter nine, is demonstrative of that and he leads the people in a prayer of right understanding of what the story of the whole Old Testament is about. Well, we get something that echoes that profoundly in Acts, chapter seven, 470-ish. I'm making that number up. That's got to be close, right? 444, that's 440 years. This is probably around 30 or 33. So yeah, I mean, 470, 480 years later, here in Acts, chapter seven, we get a passage that echoes the prayer of Nehemiah, chapter nine, but this time, instead of the people repeating the prayer of Ezra that recounts the story, all with the point of driving toward we were wrong, you were right, we renew our covenant with you. Here in Acts, chapter seven, Stephen is talking to a bunch of the Jewish leaders who have rejected and brought about the execution of Jesus and who are about to kill him, spoiler alert, and with Stephen's final words, he takes a trip through the Old Testament, talking about God's faithfulness. And the punchline of Stephen's account in chapter seven as an echo of the prayer of Nehemiah, chapter nine, is that in Nehemiah, chapter nine, all the descendants of Abraham agreed together in, well, really the whole thing, verse 29, especially, that they have been stubborn, that they have turned their backs on God, that they became stiff-necked and refused to listen. That's something they all assent to. They say they persecuted the prophets, that they rejected the messages that God sent them, that they totally fumbled it and got it wrong, even though God was putting the truth of what was happening right in front of their faces. Well, in this account in Acts, chapter seven, Stephen is basically going to say, yeah, I more or less agree with you on what the point of the whole story was that you recounted back there in Nehemiah, chapter nine, except now you are the ones who are stiff-necked. You are the ones who have rejected what God has done in front of you. You are the ones who are stubborn. You are the ones who have refused to listen. And I think this thing that Stephen says to the religious leaders in Acts, chapter seven, is very powerful if you're not that familiar with the Old Testament, but it's even more powerful if you had just got done looking at Nehemiah, chapter nine. So a bunch of the religious leaders in Acts, chapter six, says they stirred up the people and the elders and the teachers of the law and they seized Stephen and brought him before the Sanhedrin. Then these critics, they produced false witnesses. It's a lot like what happened to Jesus who testified, this fellow never stopped speaking against this holy place and against the law. Oh, remember the formal charge that got Jesus executed was blaspheming the temple. Now they're trying to tag this on to Stephen, one of his early followers as well. For we've heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs Moses handed down to us. All who were sitting in the Sanhedrin looked intently at Stephen and they saw that his face was like the face of an angel. Okay. So they're conflicted here at the end of chapter six. Everything is powerful about this young man, but the charges being brought against him echo those brought against Jesus and they just had Jesus executed for exactly those charges. Then the high priest, this is Acts seven said to him, are these charges true? This all rings a bell, right? This sounds just like the trial of Jesus and how they wanted Jesus to say it, but Jesus kept bouncing it back to them and then even saying like, Hey, you have said it is so here. Stephen just tears right into it. He plays a different role in the whole unfolding of the kingdom stuff. Acts seven to this he replied, brothers and fathers, listen to me, the God of glory appeared to our father Abraham while he was still in Mesopotamia before he lived in Huron. And what I'm about to do right here is going to take longer than the amount of time we have left. So we've set the table. We'll pick right up where we left off today, tomorrow with Acts chapter seven and Stephen giving a recounting of the story of the descendants of Abraham in the Old Testament that echoes the one in Nehemiah chapter nine, but with a very different punchline. Cool. I'm at this is a 10 minute Bible hour podcast. Let's do this again soon. This podcast exists because many of you kick in to make it happen even though you don't have to learn more at the Tmbh.com slash support. We're grateful because that supports our family. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
